elements.content: Two nonlinear optical fluoride carbonate crystals (Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2) have been synthesized under subcritical hydrothermal condition. Both crystals crystallize in the noncentrosymmetric space group Cc (No. 9). The structure of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 with high density of [CO3] groups is described as 1D [Na5Lu(CO3)2F2] chains connected by [CO3] triangles, forming an intricate three-dimensional framework. Lu3+ and Na+ cations are alternatively ordered and disordered in the cavities of the 3D network. The structure of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 is built up from the [NaLu(CO3)2F2] layers which are separated by other Na+ cations. The [CO3] anionic groups arrange approximately coparallel to the plane. The second harmonic generation (SHG) measurement indicates that Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 have large SHG responses that are approximately 4.29 and 4.21 times KH2PO4 (KDP), respectively. The responses are also phase-matchable in the visible region. In addition, it exhibits wide transparent regions ranging from UV to near IR with a short UV cutoff edge (<200 nm), which suggests that the new compounds are promising as deep-UV NLO materials.

elements.content: With the development of laser science and technology, nonlinear optical (NLO) crystals that can produce deep-UV coherent light (λ < 200 nm) are gaining in importance and attracting intensive attention. In the past decade, research on new deep-UV NLO materials has focused on borates, which lead to the discovery of many excellent deep-UV NLO crystals. In spite of many reports in the literature, it is still challenging to obtain practical NLO crystals with high NLO coefficients and wide UV transparency for practical applications, especially those covering the deep-UV region.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With the development of laser science and technology, nonlinear optical (NLO) crystals that can produce deep-UV coherent light (λ < 200 nm) are gaining in importance and attracting intensive attention. In the past decade, research on new deep-UV NLO materials has focused on borates, which lead to the discovery of many excellent deep-UV NLO crystals. In spite of many reports in the literature, it is still challenging to obtain practical NLO crystals with high NLO coefficients and wide UV transparency for practical applications, especially those covering the deep-UV region.

elements.content: Large NLO effects can be realized when favorable NLO-active structure units exist in high density and coparallel aligned in the crystal. According to the anionic group theory, the favorable basic structure unit is the planar [BO3]3– with π-orbitals in the borate system, possessing a moderate birefringence and a large microscopic second-order susceptibility β(2). Examples of such crystals include KBe2BO3F2, Sr2Be2B2O7, and K2Al2B2O7. Analogously, [NO3]− and [CO3]2– groups having the similar planar triangle structure with π-orbitals are expected to be good NLO-active anionic groups as well. Since nitrates are susceptible to hydrolysis, they are not considered as the NLO candidates. [CO3]2– ion was chosen to be the fundamental anionic group to design novel deep-UV NLO materials because most carbonates have stable physical and chemical properties.
elements.clean_text: Large NLO effects can be realized when favorable NLO-active structure units exist in high density and coparallel aligned in the crystal. According to the anionic group theory, the favorable basic structure unit is the planar [BO3]3- with π-orbitals in the borate system, possessing a moderate birefringence and a large microscopic second-order susceptibility β(2). Examples of such crystals include KBe2BO3F2, Sr2Be2B2O7, and K2Al2B2O7. Analogously, [NO3]- and [CO3]2- groups having the similar planar triangle structure with π-orbitals are expected to be good NLO-active anionic groups as well. Since nitrates are susceptible to hydrolysis, they are not considered as the NLO candidates. [CO3]2- ion was chosen to be the fundamental anionic group to design novel deep-UV NLO materials because most carbonates have stable physical and chemical properties.

elements.content: Beside carbonates, we also included alkali metal, rare earth, and halogen fluorine atoms in the novel deep-UV crystals based on the following reasoning. First, metal cations, especially the alkaline cations, often contribute to the cutoff edge shift to the UV region, because the d–d or f–f electronic transitions in the closed d or f orbitals have negative influences on the energy band gap. Second, halogen fluorine atoms in NLO crystals such as KBe2BO3F2, NaSr3Be3B3O9F4, and ABCO3F (A = K, Rb, Cs; B = Ca, Sr, Ba) can cause a blue shift in the absorption spectra. This is because the strong electronegativity of fluorine atoms would cause a large energy band gap, thus resulting in short UV cutoff edge in the compound. Third, compounds that contain rare earth atoms usually exhibit excellent optical properties, for example, YAl3(BO3)4 (YAB), LuAl3(BO3)4 (LAB), Y0.57La0.72Sc2.71(BO3)4 (YLSB),Cd4ReO (BO3)3 (Re = Y, Gd, Lu), and GdCa4(BO3)3 (GCOB). Our present study on noncentrosymmetric materials Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, which exhibited a short UV cutoff edge (<200 nm) and a large SHG effect, were based on systematical synthesis of alkali metal (Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs) and rare earth (La, Sc, Y, Gd, Lu) fluoride carbonate systems under subcritical hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: To our knowledge, few rare earth fluoride-carbonate NLO materials have been reported so far. NLO property has only been observed in K4Ln2(CO3)3F4 (where Ln = Nd, Sm, Eu, and Gd). We report the first example of utilizing rare earth atoms, whose 4f orbital is full of electrons, to design deep UV fluoride carbonate crystals. Detailed in this work are the syntheses, crystal structures, thermal behaviors, and linear and nonlinear optical properties of the two sodium–lutetium fluoride carbonates.

Detailed in this work are the syntheses, crystal structures, thermal behaviors, and linear and nonlinear optical properties of the two sodium-lutetium fluoride carbonates.

elements.content:
Na2CO3 (99.8%) and NaF (99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm. Lu(NO3)3·6H2O(99.0%) was purchased from Jinan Camolai Trading Company.

Syntheses of Na<sub>8</sub>Lu<sub>2</sub>(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>6</sub>F<sub>2</sub>

Na2CO3 (0.212 g, 0.002 mol), NaF (0.0504 g, 0.0012 mol), and Lu(NO3)3·6H2O (0.181 g, 0.0004 mol) were dissolved in H2O (5.0 mL). The fully mixed solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 180 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless brick-shaped Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 crystals were obtained with a small amount of side product Na3Lu(CO3)2F2.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents

Na2CO3 (99.8%) and NaF (99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm. Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O(99.0%) was purchased from Jinan Camolai Trading Company.

Syntheses of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 

Na2CO3 (0.212 g, 0.002 mol), NaF (0.0504 g, 0.0012 mol), and Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.181 g, 0.0004 mol) were dissolved in H2O (5.0 mL). The fully mixed solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 180 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless brick-shaped Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 crystals were obtained with a small amount of side product Na3Lu(CO3)2F2.

elements.content: Optimization of the synthesis was carried out to minimize the side product. Increasing the concentration of Na2CO3 resulted in more Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and the less Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. When the concentration of Na2CO3 reached 2 mol/L with all other experimental conditions remaining the same, Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 was obtained as a single phase with the yield of about 92% based on the analysis of Lu. Side product Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 disappeared completely.

elements.content: Na2CO3 (0.318 g 0.003 mol), NaF (0.063 g 0.0015 mol), and Lu(NO3)3·6H2O (0.235 g, 0.0005 mol) were dissolved in H2O (10.0 mL). The solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 220 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless plates of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 crystals were obtained with needle-shaped crystals of Na2Lu(CO3)2F and a small amount of side products Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O. Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O were found to be isostructural with Na2Yb(CO3)2F and Na5Sc(CO3)4·2H2O, respectively. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O are summarized in Table S1(). Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S2–S3 ().

Syntheses of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 

Na2CO3 (0.318 g 0.003 mol), NaF (0.063 g 0.0015 mol), and Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.235 g, 0.0005 mol) were dissolved in H2O (10.0 mL). The solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 220 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless plates of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 crystals were obtained with needle-shaped crystals of Na2Lu(CO3)2F and a small amount of side products Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na5Lu(CO3)4⋅2H2O. Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4⋅2H2O were found to be isostructural with Na2Yb(CO3)2F and Na5Sc(CO3)4⋅2H2O, respectively. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4⋅2H2O are summarized in Table S1(). Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S2-S3 ().

elements.content: Experimental conditions such as stoichiometry and temperature were optimized to minimize side products. By keeping the stoichiometry constant and varying the temperature, it was found that a high yield of about 90% (based on Lu) for the major phase Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 was achieved at 250 °C. Meanwhile, side product Na2Lu(CO3)2F disappeared completely. However, there was still Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O in the product at an extremely low percentage (far below 1%).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 were collected at room temperature on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer and a computer-controlled XCalibur E CCD diffractometer, respectively, both equipped with a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A transparent block of crystal was mounted on a glass fiber with epoxy for structure determination. The intensity data sets were corrected with the ω-scan technique. The data for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 were integrated using the CrystalClear program, and absorption corrections based on the Multiscan technique were also applied. The CryAlisPro software was used for date reduction and empirical absorption correction for Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The structure of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 was solved by the direct methods. The structure of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 was solved by analyzing atom sites of the isostructural crystal Na3Yb(CO3)2F2. During the refinement for Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, Na and Lu atoms were set to share the same sites, due to the large U(eq) and R values when these sites were assigned as Lu atoms. To retain charge balance, the molar ratio of Na/Lu was fixed to 1:1 in the disorder sites. Elemental analysis of Na and Lu in the single crystal was performed. The result indicated that the sodium content was 16.60 wt % and the lutetium content was 43.27 wt %, which were consistent with the calculated ones (Na: 17.16 wt % and Lu: 43.53 wt %). Then they were refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All of the structures were verified using the ADDSYM algorithm from the program PLATON, and no higher symmetries were found. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are summarized in Table . Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S4–S5 () and bond lengths in Tables S6–S7 in the .

Single Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 were collected at room temperature on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer and a computer-controlled XCalibur E CCD diffractometer, respectively, both equipped with a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A transparent block of crystal was mounted on a glass fiber with epoxy for structure determination. The intensity data sets were corrected with the ω-scan technique. The data for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 were integrated using the CrystalClear program, and absorption corrections based on the Multiscan technique were also applied. The CryAlisPro software was used for date reduction and empirical absorption correction for Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The structure of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 was solved by the direct methods. The structure of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 was solved by analyzing atom sites of the isostructural crystal Na3Yb(CO3)2F2. During the refinement for Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, Na and Lu atoms were set to share the same sites, due to the large U(eq) and R values when these sites were assigned as Lu atoms. To retain charge balance, the molar ratio of Na/Lu was fixed to 1:1 in the disorder sites. Elemental analysis of Na and Lu in the single crystal was performed. The result indicated that the sodium content was 16.60 wt % and the lutetium content was 43.27 wt %, which were consistent with the calculated ones (Na: 17.16 wt % and Lu: 43.53 wt %). Then they were refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All of the structures were verified using the ADDSYM algorithm from the program PLATON, and no higher symmetries were found. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are summarized in Table . X-ray diffraction patterns of polycrystalline materials were obtained at room temperature on a Rigaku Dmax2500 powder X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) in the angular range of 2θ = 5–65° with a scan step width of 0.05° and a fixed time of 0.2 s. The powder XRD patterns for the pure powder samples of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 showed good agreement with the calculated XRD patterns from the single-crystal models (see Figure S1 in the ).

elements.content: The TG/DTA scans were performed on a SDT Q600 simultaneous analyzer. Reference (Al2O3) and crystal samples (3–10 mg) were enclosed in Al2O3 crucibles and heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a constant flow of nitrogen gas.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The TG/DTA scans were performed on a SDT Q600 simultaneous analyzer. Reference (Al2O3) and crystal samples (3-10 mg) were enclosed in Al2O3 crucibles and heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a constant flow of nitrogen gas.

elements.content: UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded at room temperature on a powder sample with BaSO4 as a standard (100% reflectance). Data were collected on a PerkinElmer Lamda-900 UV/vis/NIR spectrophotometer scanning in the range of 200–2500 nm. Reflectance values were converted to absorbance using the Kubelka–Munk function.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy

UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded at room temperature on a powder sample with BaSO4 as a standard (100% reflectance). Data were collected on a PerkinElmer Lamda-900 UV/vis/NIR spectrophotometer scanning in the range of 200-2500 nm. Reflectance values were converted to absorbance using the Kubelka-Munk function.

elements.content: Powder second-harmonic generation (SHG) signals were measured using the method adapted from Kurtz and Perry. Since SHG efficiencies are known to depend strongly on particle size, polycrystalline samples were ground and sieved into the following particle size ranges: 25–45, 45–62, 62–75, 75–109, 109–150, and 150–212 μm. The samples were pressed between glass microscope cover slides and secured with tape in 1-mm thick aluminum holders containing an 8-mm diameter hole. To make relevant comparisons with known SHG materials, crystalline KH2PO4 (KDP) were also ground and sieved into the same particle size ranges. The samples were then placed in a light-tight box and irradiated with a pulsed laser. The measurements were performed with a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at the wavelength of 1064 nm. A cutoff filter was used to limit background flash-lamp light on the sample. An interference filter (530 ± 10 nm) was used to select the second harmonic for detection with a photomultiplier tube attached to a RIGOL DS1052E 50-MHz oscilloscope. This procedure was then repeated using the standard nonlinear optical materials KDP, and the ratio of the second-harmonic intensity outputs was calculated. No index-matching fluid was used in any of the experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Second-Harmonic Generation

Powder second-harmonic generation (SHG) signals were measured using the method adapted from Kurtz and Perry. Since SHG efficiencies are known to depend strongly on particle size, polycrystalline samples were ground and sieved into the following particle size ranges: 25-45, 45-62, 62-75, 75-109, 109-150, and 150-212 μm. The samples were pressed between glass microscope cover slides and secured with tape in 1-mm thick aluminum holders containing an 8-mm diameter hole. To make relevant comparisons with known SHG materials, crystalline KH2PO4 (KDP) were also ground and sieved into the same particle size ranges. The samples were then placed in a light-tight box and irradiated with a pulsed laser. The measurements were performed with a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at the wavelength of 1064 nm. A cutoff filter was used to limit background flash-lamp light on the sample. An interference filter (530 ± 10 nm) was used to select the second harmonic for detection with a photomultiplier tube attached to a RIGOL DS1052E 50-MHz oscilloscope. This procedure was then repeated using the standard nonlinear optical materials KDP, and the ratio of the second-harmonic intensity outputs was calculated. No index-matching fluid was used in any of the experiments.

elements.content: Electronic structure and optical properties of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 were analyzed using density functional theory (DFT) calculation with CASTEP code provided by the Material Studio package. Interaction of the electrons with ion cores was represented by the norm-conserving pseudopotentials, and the valence electrons were treated as C, 2s22p2; O, 2s22p4; F, 2s22p5; Na, 2s22p63s1; Lu, 4f145s25p65d16s2. Generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the scheme of Perdew–Burke–Eruzerhof (PBE) was used to describe the exchange and correlative potential of electron–electron interactions. The k-point of first Brillouin zone was sampled as 2 × 2 × 1 and 2 × 2 × 2 Monkhorst–Pack scheme for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, respectively. Energy cutoff and precision were set to be 780 eV and 2.0 × 10–5 eV/atom. In the optical properties calculation, higher energy cutoff, and precision was adopted at 900 eV and 2.0 × 10–5 eV/atom, respectively, and 1000 extra unoccupied bands were added. The X-ray crystal structure data were used without further optimization. The disorder occupation of Na and Lu in Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 was chosen as Lu(1) occupied by Lu and Lu(2) occupied by Na atom.
elements.clean_text:
First-Principles Calculations

Electronic structure and optical properties of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 were analyzed using density functional theory (DFT) calculation with CASTEP code provided by the Material Studio package. Interaction of the electrons with ion cores was represented by the norm-conserving pseudopotentials, and the valence electrons were treated as C, 2s22p2; O, 2s22p4; F, 2s22p5; Na, 2s22p63s1; Lu, 4f145s25p65d16s2. Generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the scheme of Perdew-Burke-Eruzerhof (PBE) was used to describe the exchange and correlative potential of electron-electron interactions. The k-point of first Brillouin zone was sampled as 2 × 2 × 1 and 2 × 2 × 2 Monkhorst-Pack scheme for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, respectively. Energy cutoff and precision were set to be 780 eV and 2.0 × 10-5 eV/atom. In the optical properties calculation, higher energy cutoff, and precision was adopted at 900 eV and 2.0 × 10-5 eV/atom, respectively, and 1000 extra unoccupied bands were added. The X-ray crystal structure data were used without further optimization. The disorder occupation of Na and Lu in Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 was chosen as Lu(1) occupied by Lu and Lu(2) occupied by Na atom.

elements.content: This was derived from a classical anharmonic oscillator (AHO) model.The first-order susceptibility χ(1) ii in the low frequency region is given by χ(1)(ω) ii = [ε(ω) ii – 1]/4π where the dielectric function ε 2 i j ( ω ) = 8 π 2 ℏ 2 e 2 m 2 V eff Σ k Σ c v ( f c − f v ) p c v i ( k ) p v c i ( k ) E v c 2 δ [ E c ( k ) − E v ( k ) − ℏ ω ] In this expression, δ[E c (k) – E v (k) – ℏω] denotes the energy difference between the conduction and valence bands at the k point with absorption of a quantum ℏω. f c and f v represent the Fermi distribution functions of the conduction and valence bands, respectively. Due to the well-known underestimation of band gap for DFT method, the scissors operation was applied to E c (k) in the dielectric function calculation.

elements.content: Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 crystallizes into a monoclinic crystal system with a noncentrosymmetric space group of Cc. As shown in Figure , the structure can be described as 1D [Na5Lu(CO3)2F2] chains connected by C(2)O3, C(3)O3, C(5)O3, and C(6)O3 groups, forming an intricate three-dimensional framework. The Na(2), Na(3), Na(8), and Lu(1) atoms are located in the cavities of the 3D network. The Na(2) and Na(8) atoms are sevenfold coordinated, respectively, forming [Na(2)O7] and [Na(8)O6F] polyhedral. Na(3) atoms are sixfold coordinated, forming [Na(3)O6] polyhedra. The other Na atoms are surrounded by five O atoms and one F atom, forming [NaO5F] polyhedra. The Lu atom possesses two distinctive coordination environments. The Lu(1) atom is surrounded by eight O atoms, forming [Lu(1)O8] polyhedra. The Lu(2) atom is surrounded by five O atoms and two F atoms, forming [Lu(2)O5F2] polyhedra. The carbonate groups form rods along the c-axis that can be described as piercing or cross-linking (on-edge) infinite corrugated sheets of edge sharing (Figure b). In terms of structure, the C atoms are coordinated to three O atoms to form planar [CO3] triangles with C–O bond lengths ranging from 1.234(8) to 1.342(7) Å and O–C–O bond angles ranging from 114.9(6) to 123.2(6)°. One-third of the [CO3] groups are approximately parallel to the a–b plane and in the same direction, contributing most to the SHG effect. The other [CO3] groups are inclined to the a–b plane giving additional contributions to the SHG effect.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 

Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 crystallizes into a monoclinic crystal system with a noncentrosymmetric space group of Cc. As shown in Figure , the structure can be described as 1D [Na5Lu(CO3)2F2] chains connected by C(2)O3, C(3)O3, C(5)O3, and C(6)O3 groups, forming an intricate three-dimensional framework. The Na(2), Na(3), Na(8), and Lu(1) atoms are located in the cavities of the 3D network. The Na(2) and Na(8) atoms are sevenfold coordinated, respectively, forming [Na(2)O7] and [Na(8)O6F] polyhedral. Na(3) atoms are sixfold coordinated, forming [Na(3)O6] polyhedra. The other Na atoms are surrounded by five O atoms and one F atom, forming [NaO5F] polyhedra. The Lu atom possesses two distinctive coordination environments. The Lu(1) atom is surrounded by eight O atoms, forming [Lu(1)O8] polyhedra. The Lu(2) atom is surrounded by five O atoms and two F atoms, forming [Lu(2)O5F2] polyhedra. The carbonate groups form rods along the c-axis that can be described as piercing or cross-linking (on-edge) infinite corrugated sheets of edge sharing (Figure b). In terms of structure, the C atoms are coordinated to three O atoms to form planar [CO3] triangles with C-O bond lengths ranging from 1.234(8) to 1.342(7) Å and O-C-O bond angles ranging from 114.9(6) to 123.2(6)°. One-third of the [CO3] groups are approximately parallel to the a-b plane and in the same direction, contributing most to the SHG effect. The other [CO3] groups are inclined to the a-b plane giving additional contributions to the SHG effect.

elements.content: Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, being isostructural to Na3Yb(CO3)2F2, crystallizes into a monoclinic crystal system with a noncentrosymmetric space group of Cc. As shown in Figure a, the structure can be described from (010) layers [(Lu0.5Na0.5)2(CO3)2F2]∞ (Figure b) and [Lu(3)Na(3)(CO3)2F2]∞ (Figure c) separated by Na(4), Na(5), Na(6), and Na(7) atoms. In terms of structure, one over two Lu atoms is disordered with one over six Na atoms on two crystallographic sites (Lu0.5Na0.5) (1), (Lu0.5Na0.5) (2), which are surrounded by five O atoms and two F atoms, forming [Lu0.5Na0.5O5F2] polyhedra. Lu(3) atoms are also sevenfold coordinated, forming [LuO5F2] pentagonal bipyramid. Na(5), Na(6), and Na(7) atoms are sixfold coordinated, while Na(3) and Na(4) atoms are fivefold and sevenfold coordinated, respectively, forming [NaO n ] (n = 5, 6, 7) polyhedra. The C atoms are coordinated to three O atoms to form planar [CO3] triangles with C–O bond lengths ranging from 1.229(1) to 1336(1) Å and O–C–O bond angles ranging from 113.3(1) to 125.2(1)°. In this structure, the arrangement of anionic groups [CO3] forms a well-defined plane, and the [CO3] groups are approximately parallel. This has close to maximum contribution to a large macroscopic SHG effect.

Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 

Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, being isostructural to Na3Yb(CO3)2F2, crystallizes into a monoclinic crystal system with a noncentrosymmetric space group of Cc. As shown in Figure a, the structure can be described from (010) layers [(Lu0.5Na0.5)2(CO3)2F2]∞ (Figure b) and [Lu(3)Na(3)(CO3)2F2]∞ (Figure c) separated by Na(4), Na(5), Na(6), and Na(7) atoms. In terms of structure, one over two Lu atoms is disordered with one over six Na atoms on two crystallographic sites (Lu0.5Na0.5) (1), (Lu0.5Na0.5) (2), which are surrounded by five O atoms and two F atoms, forming [Lu0.5Na0.5O5F2] polyhedra. Lu(3) atoms are also sevenfold coordinated, forming [LuO5F2] pentagonal bipyramid. Na(5), Na(6), and Na(7) atoms are sixfold coordinated, while Na(3) and Na(4) atoms are fivefold and sevenfold coordinated, respectively, forming [NaO n ] (n = 5, 6, 7) polyhedra. The C atoms are coordinated to three O atoms to form planar [CO3] triangles with C-O bond lengths ranging from 1.229(1) to 1336(1) Å and O-C-O bond angles ranging from 113.3(1) to 125.2(1)°. In this structure, the arrangement of anionic groups [CO3] forms a well-defined plane, and the [CO3] groups are approximately parallel. This has close to maximum contribution to a large macroscopic SHG effect.

elements.content: The thermal behavior of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 is shown in . TG analysis curves of two compounds exhibit weight losses in two steps. The first step in Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2, which occurs in the temperature range of about 300–500 °C, is attributed to the loss (weight %) of 3 mol of CO2 vapor per mol of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 (exp./th. = 15.4/14.7). The decomposition reaction is Na 8 Lu 2 ( CO 3 ) 6 F 2 → 3 Na 2 CO 3 + Lu 2 O 3 + 2 NaF + 3 CO 2 ( g )

For both compounds, the second step corresponds to the decomposition of Na2CO3.

Optical Properties

UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected for all of the reported compounds; see Figure . Absorption (K/S) data were calculated from the following KubelkaMunk function: F(R) = (1 – R)2/2R = K/S, where R is the reflectance, K is the absorption, and S is the scattering. In the (K/S) vs E plots, extrapolating the linear part of the rising curve to zero provided the onset of absorption. No obvious absorption peak in the range of 6.20–0.496 eV corresponding to 200–2500 nm was observed for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The results indicate that these crystals may be potentially applied in deep-UV NLO materials.

elements.content: Figure shows the SHG signal as a function of particle size from the measurements made on ground crystals of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The results are consistent with phase-matching behaviors according to the rule proposed by Kurtz and Perry. A KDP sample was selected as the reference. The second-harmonic signal was found to be 4.29 and 4.21 KDP for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, respectively. These values are proportional to the squares of the nonlinear d eff coefficients. Since the reported d 36 coefficient for KDP is 0.39 pm/V, the derived d eff coefficients for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are 1.67 and 1.64 pm/V, respectively.

NLO Properties

Figure  shows the SHG signal as a function of particle size from the measurements made on ground crystals of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The results are consistent with phase-matching behaviors according to the rule proposed by Kurtz and Perry. A KDP sample was selected as the reference. The second-harmonic signal was found to be 4.29 and 4.21 KDP for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, respectively. These values are proportional to the squares of the nonlinear d eff coefficients. Since the reported d 36 coefficient for KDP is 0.39 pm/V, the derived d eff coefficients for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are 1.67 and 1.64 pm/V, respectively.

elements.content: On the basis of the anionic group theory, the dipole transition from the cations to the anionic group ([CO3] in this case) is the off-site transition. Its value is about 1 order smaller than the dipole transition of the intra-atomic transitions within anionic groups. So the contribution to the main SHG coefficients from the anionic group [CO3] is dominant, which is much larger than that of the charge transfer between the s-states of cations and the p-originated states of anions. Therefore, the macroscopic second-order susceptibility χ(2) may be expressed by eq , x i j k ( 2 ) = F V ∑ p ∑ i ′ j ′ k ′ α ii ′ α jj ′ α kk ′ β i ′ j ′ k ′ ( 2 ) ( P ) , ⁣ P = [ CO 3 ] where F is the correction factor of the localized field, V is the volume of the unit cell, α ii′, α jj′, and α kk′ are the direction cosines between the macroscopic coordinate axes of the crystal and the microscopic coordinate axes of [CO3 ] groups, and β i′j′k′ are the microscopic second-order susceptibility tensors of an individual group. Owing to the fact that [CO3] is a planar group in point group D 3h , there are only two nonvanishing second-order susceptibility β111 (2) = β222 (2) under the Kleinman approximation. Because the geometrical factor, g, can be derived from eq , eq may be simplified according to the deduction process shown in ref : x i j k ( 2 ) = F V · g i j k · β 111 2 ( [ C O 3 ] )

Assuming equal localized field (F) based on their similar refractive indices, we know from the eq and eq that the NLO coefficient χ ijk (2) is proportional to density of the [CO3] group (n/V) and the structural criterion (C). The [CO3] groups in Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are approximately in coparallel alignment, giving close to 100% optimum which comes from the contribution of g 333. For Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2, one-third of the [CO3] groups are approximately parallel to the a–b plane giving major contribution to the C factor. The other [CO3] groups are inclined to the a–b plane giving additional contributions to the C factor. The calculated value of C factor for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 is 86%. Although the C factor of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 is lower than that of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, the experiment SHG values are close to each other. This is because the density of the [CO3] group for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 (0.0138) is higher than that of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 (0.0119). In order to further illustrate the SHG effects as determined by the arrangement of the NLO-active groups and the density of NLO-active groups, we compared the two compounds with KSrCO3F. Although the structural criterion C of the two compounds is lower than that of KSrCO3F, their SHG coefficient is larger than that of KSrCO3F. On the other hand, the two compounds have higher density of [CO3] groups than KSrCO3F. Moreover, the two compounds have moderate C values. These result in larger SHG effects in our compounds as compared to KSrCO3F. As shown in Table , the above argument on the structure–properties correlations is in good agreement with the SHG measurement.

The band structures are presented in Figure S3 (). Compounds Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 exhibit direct band gaps of 4.129 and 3.355 eV, respectively. These values are smaller than the experimental values due to the underestimation of band gap by DFT method. Since no obvious absorption peak in the range of 6.20–0.496 eV (corresponding to 200–2500 nm) was observed for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 in the UVvis diffuse reflectance spectra, we assume that the band gaps of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are both 6.20 eV. Therefore, scissor values of 2.071 and 2.845 eV for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, respectively, are applied to the subsequent SHG calculations.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

The band structures are presented in Figure S3 (). Compounds Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 exhibit direct band gaps of 4.129 and 3.355 eV, respectively. These values are smaller than the experimental values due to the underestimation of band gap by DFT method. Since no obvious absorption peak in the range of 6.20-0.496 eV (corresponding to 200-2500 nm) was observed for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 in the UVvis diffuse reflectance spectra, we assume that the band gaps of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are both 6.20 eV. Therefore, scissor values of 2.071 and 2.845 eV for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, respectively, are applied to the subsequent SHG calculations.

elements.content: The total and partial densities of states (DOS and PDOS) for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are presented in Figure . Only the upper region of the valence band (VB) and the bottom of conduction band (CB) are shown because linear and nonlinear optical properties are mainly determined by the states close to the forbidden band. It is obvious that the contribution from the Na orbitals can almost be neglected in these states. Meanwhile, the F orbitals and Lu orbitals are located below 3.7 and 2.7 eV from the VB maximum, respectively. The VB maximum and CB minimum are composed of the O 2p and C 2p orbitals, respectively, thus indicating great contribution from the CO3 polyhedra to the SHG coefficients.

elements.content: The space group of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, both belonging to class m, has 10 nonvanishing tensors of second-order susceptibility. Under the restriction of Kleinman’s symmetry, only six independent SHG tensor components (d 11, d 12, d 13, d 15, d 24, and d 33) were considered. The calculated six frequency-dependent NLO components (d 11, d 12, d 13, d 15, d 24, and d 33) of the Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 were plotted in Figure . For Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2, The values of d 11, d 12, d 13, d 15, d 24, and d 33 at a wavelength of 1064 nm (1.165 eV) are 4.05 × 10–9, 4.04 × 10–9, 2.44 × 10–9, 3.14 × 10–9, 3.15 × 10–9, and 1.87 × 10–9 esu, respectively. For Na3Lu(CO3)2F2, the values of d 11, d 12, d 13, d 15, d 24, and d 33 at a wavelength of 1064 nm (1.165 eV) are 2.82 × 10–9, 3.81 × 10–9, 2.83 × 10–9, 2.71 × 10–9, 4.01 × 10–9, and 4.64 × 10–9 esu, respectively. The calculated values are consistent with the experimental values, which are about four times that of KDP (d 36 = 1.1 × 10–9 esu) for the two compounds, respectively. To obtained d in the units of pm/V, it is necessary to multiply each entry by 4.189 × 108. For example, we have max d ij values, 4.05 × 10–9 esu × 4.189 × 108 = 1.70 pm/V and 4.64 × 10–9 esu × 4.189 × 108 = 1.94 pm/V, respectively, for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The largest d components for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 are d 11 and d 33, respectively, which match well with the results predicted by the geometrical factor calculations on the basis of anionic group theory in . This also proves that the NLO coefficients of these two fluoride carbonates are mainly originated from the [CO3] NLO-active groups.

elements.content: In summary, Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 with noncentrosymmetric structure have been prepared under subcritical hydrothermal condition. The UV–vis–IR diffuse reflectance analysis of the powder samples of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 indicates that the short-wavelength absorption edge is below 200 nm. The SHG test shows that the compounds exhibit SHG responses about 4.29 and 4.21 times KH2PO4 (KDP), respectively, for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The relatively large SHG coefficients of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 likely originate from the high density of [CO3] and relatively suitable [CO3] arrangement. The wide transparency range and large SHG effects make these two compounds potential deep-UV NLO materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 with noncentrosymmetric structure have been prepared under subcritical hydrothermal condition. The UV-vis-IR diffuse reflectance analysis of the powder samples of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 indicates that the short-wavelength absorption edge is below 200 nm. The SHG test shows that the compounds exhibit SHG responses about 4.29 and 4.21 times KH2PO4 (KDP), respectively, for Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2. The relatively large SHG coefficients of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 likely originate from the high density of [CO3] and relatively suitable [CO3] arrangement. The wide transparency range and large SHG effects make these two compounds potential deep-UV NLO materials.

cln_elements.content:
Na2CO3 (99.8%) and NaF (99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm. Lu(NO3)3·6H2O(99.0%) was purchased from Jinan Camolai Trading Company.

Syntheses of Na<sub>8</sub>Lu<sub>2</sub>(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>6</sub>F<sub>2</sub>

Na2CO3 (0.212 g, 0.002 mol), NaF (0.0504 g, 0.0012 mol), and Lu(NO3)3·6H2O (0.181 g, 0.0004 mol) were dissolved in H2O (5.0 mL). The fully mixed solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 180 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless brick-shaped Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 crystals were obtained with a small amount of side product Na3Lu(CO3)2F2.

Syntheses of Na<sub>3</sub>Lu(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>F<sub>2</sub>

Na2CO3 (0.318 g 0.003 mol), NaF (0.063 g 0.0015 mol), and Lu(NO3)3·6H2O (0.235 g, 0.0005 mol) were dissolved in H2O (10.0 mL). The solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 220 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless plates of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 crystals were obtained with needle-shaped crystals of Na2Lu(CO3)2F and a small amount of side products Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O. Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O were found to be isostructural with Na2Yb(CO3)2F and Na5Sc(CO3)4·2H2O, respectively. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4·2H2O are summarized in Table S1(). Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S2–S3 ().

Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 undergoes the first weight loss between 350 and 550 °C due to the release of 1.5 mols of CO2(exp./th. = 17.4/16.4). The decomposition reaction is Na 3 Lu ( CO 3 ) 2 F 2 → 0.5 Na 2 CO 3 + 0.5 Lu 2 O 3 + 2 NaF + 1.5 CO 2 ( g )

Experimental Section

Reagents

Na2CO3 (99.8%) and NaF (99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm. Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O(99.0%) was purchased from Jinan Camolai Trading Company.

Syntheses of Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 

Na2CO3 (0.212 g, 0.002 mol), NaF (0.0504 g, 0.0012 mol), and Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.181 g, 0.0004 mol) were dissolved in H2O (5.0 mL). The fully mixed solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 180 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless brick-shaped Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 crystals were obtained with a small amount of side product Na3Lu(CO3)2F2.

Syntheses of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 

Na2CO3 (0.318 g 0.003 mol), NaF (0.063 g 0.0015 mol), and Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.235 g, 0.0005 mol) were dissolved in H2O (10.0 mL). The solution was sealed in an autoclave equipped with a Teflon liner (23 mL) and heated at 220 °C for 5 days, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 3 °C/h. The reaction product was washed with deionized water and ethanol and then dried in the air. Colorless plates of Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 crystals were obtained with needle-shaped crystals of Na2Lu(CO3)2F and a small amount of side products Na8Lu2(CO3)6F2 and Na5Lu(CO3)4⋅2H2O. Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4⋅2H2O were found to be isostructural with Na2Yb(CO3)2F and Na5Sc(CO3)4⋅2H2O, respectively. Relevant crystallographic data and details of the experimental conditions for Na2Lu(CO3)2F and Na5Lu(CO3)4⋅2H2O are summarized in Table S1(). Atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement coefficients are listed in Tables S2-S3 ().

Na3Lu(CO3)2F2 undergoes the first weight loss between 350 and 550 °C due to the release of 1.5 mols of CO2(exp./th. = 17.4/16.4). The decomposition reaction is    Na   3   Lu   (   CO   3   )   2     F   2   → 0.5   Na   2     CO   3   + 0.5   Lu   2     O   3   + 2 NaF + 1.5  CO   2  ( g )
